title: Ingrida Šimonytė
text:
Ingrida Šimonytė (; born 15 November 1974) is a Lithuanian politician and economist who is the current <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Lithuania">Prime Minister of Lithuania</a>, having taken office on 11 December 2020. Šimonytė has served as a member of the <a href="Seimas">Seimas</a> for the <a href="Antakalnis">Antakalnis</a> constituency since 2016 and was <a href="Ministry%20of%20Finance%20%28Lithuania%29">minister of finance</a> in the <a href="Kubilius%20Cabinet%20II">second Kubilius cabinet</a> from 2009 until 2012. She was a candidate in the <a href="2019%20Lithuanian%20presidential%20election">2019 presidential election</a>, but lost in the second round run-off. Šimonytė is an <a href="independent%20politician">independent politician</a>, although she has been affiliated with the <a href="Homeland%20Union">Homeland Union</a>.
Born in <a href="Vilnius">Vilnius</a>, Šimonytė graduated from <a href="Vilnius%20University">Vilnius University</a> with a degree in business in 1996, later receiving a master's degree as well in 1998. She began her career as an economist and public servant, working as chief of the tax division within the Ministry of Finance until 2004. She remained within the ministry's tax division until being nominated to serve as finance minister in 2009, tasked with stimulating the Lithuanian economy in the aftermath of the <a href="Great%20Recession">Great Recession</a>. She resigned from the position in 2012, and afterwards was appointed deputy chairperson of the Board of the <a href="Bank%20of%20Lithuania">Bank of Lithuania</a>, while also becoming chairperson of <a href="Vilnius%20University">Vilnius University</a> Council, a professor of economics at the <a href="Vilnius%20University%20Institute%20of%20International%20Relations%20and%20Political%20Science">Vilnius University Institute of International Relations and Political Science</a>, and of public finance at <a href="ISM%20University%20of%20Management%20and%20Economics">ISM University of Management and Economics</a>.
Šimonytė returned to politics in 2016, when she ran as an independent candidate in the <a href="2016%20Lithuanian%20parliamentary%20election">2016 parliamentary election</a> to represent Antakalnis constituency in Vilnius, ultimately winning a seat in parliament. In 2018, Šimonytė announced her campaign in the <a href="2019%20Lithuanian%20presidential%20election">2019 presidential election</a>, and won the nomination of the Homeland Union. She narrowly won the first round of the election on 12 May 2019, before placing second behind <a href="Gitanas%20Naus%C4%97da">Gitanas Nausėda</a> in the run-off on 26 May.
She was reelected to parliament in the <a href="2020%20Lithuanian%20parliamentary%20election">2020 parliamentary election</a>, where the Homeland Union won a plurality of seats. Following the certification of the election results, Šimonytė was proposed as the prime ministerial candidate by a coalition consisting of the Homeland Union, <a href="Liberal%20Movement%20%28Lithuania%29">Liberal Movement</a>, and <a href="Freedom%20Party%20%28Lithuania%29">Freedom Party</a>, and took office on 11 December, along with the appointment of her <a href="%C5%A0imonyt%C4%97%20Cabinet">cabinet</a>.
Early life and education.
Šimonytė was born 15 November 1974 in <a href="Vilnius">Vilnius</a> to a father who worked as a <a href="civil%20engineer">civil engineer</a>, and a mother, Danutė Šimonienė, who worked as an economist. She moved to the <a href="Antakalnis">Antakalnis</a> district of Vilnius with her parents in 1984, where she spent most of her childhood and formative years. In 1992, Šimonytė graduated from the <a href="Vilnius%20%C5%BDirm%C5%ABnai%20Gymnasium">Vilnius Žirmūnai Gymnasium</a>, where she was recognised and awarded for her academic skills in mathematics.
After graduating, she enrolled in the Faculty of Economics at <a href="Vilnius%20University">Vilnius University</a>, graduating with a degree in <a href="business%20administration">business administration</a> in 1996. She subsequently returned to the institution, and received a master's degree in economics in 1998.
Political career.
Early career.
In 1997, Šimonytė first began working professionally as an economist and <a href="public%20servant">public servant</a>, after being hired at the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Finance%20%28Lithuania%29">Ministry of Finance</a> within its tax division. Between 1998 and 2001, Šimonytė worked as an economist in the ministry's tax and sales division, and later was promoted to head of the ministry's direct taxation division, a position she remained in until 2004, when she became chancellor of the ministry, and later deputy finance minister. She resigned from this position in 2009, to take office as finance minister.
Minister of Finance.
In 2009, Šimonytė was nominated to serve as finance minister in the <a href="Kubilius%20Cabinet%20II">second cabinet</a> of <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Lithuania">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Andrius%20Kubilius">Andrius Kubilius</a>, replacing <a href="Algirdas%20%C5%A0emeta">Algirdas Šemeta</a> who had stepped down to become <a href="European%20Commissioner%20for%20Budget%20and%20Administration">European Commissioner for Budget and Administration</a>. Following her nomination, she was appointed by <a href="President%20of%20Lithuania">President</a> <a href="Valdas%20Adamkus">Valdas Adamkus</a> to serve in the office. Upon taking office, Šimonytė was tasked with recovering the Lithuanian economy in the aftermath of the <a href="Great%20Recession">Great Recession</a>, with Lithuania's <a href="gross%20domestic%20product">gross domestic product</a> (GDP) having dipped 14.7% in 2009. While in the position, Šimonytė became one of the faces of the <a href="Austerity">austerity drive</a> implemented by the government in order to improve the Lithuanian economy.
Šimonytė stepped down from her position as finance minister after the <a href="2012%20Lithuanian%20parliamentary%20election">2012 parliamentary election</a>, where the incumbent government suffered defeat at the hands of the <a href="Lithuanian%20Social%20Democratic%20Party">Lithuanian Social Democratic Party</a> and the incoming government of <a href="Algirdas%20Butkevi%C4%8Dius">Algirdas Butkevičius</a>. Following her resignation, Šimonytė was appointed to serve as deputy chairperson of the board of the <a href="Bank%20of%20Lithuania">Bank of Lithuania</a>, a role she remained in until 2016, while also becoming a lecturer of economics at the <a href="Vilnius%20University%20Institute%20of%20International%20Relations%20and%20Political%20Science">Vilnius University Institute of International Relations and Political Science</a>, and of public finance at <a href="ISM%20University%20of%20Management%20and%20Economics">ISM University of Management and Economics</a>.
Parliamentary career.
In 2015, Šimonytė planned her return to politics after confirming her intention to stand as a candidate in the <a href="2016%20Lithuanian%20parliamentary%20election">2016 parliamentary election</a>, aiming to represent the <a href="Antakalnis">Antakalnis constituency</a> within <a href="Vilnius">Vilnius</a>. The seat had been held by former <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Lithuania">prime minister</a> <a href="Andrius%20Kubilius">Andrius Kubilius</a>, who opted not to run for reelection in the constituency. Considered to be a safe seat for the <a href="Homeland%20Union">Homeland Union</a>, Šimonytė ran as an <a href="independent%20politician">independent candidate</a>, but received electoral assistance from the Homeland Union. In the election, Šimonytė was one of only three constituency candidates nationwide to win their elections without having to advance to a second round run-off election, having won 51.54% of the electorate within her constituency in the first round. Following her win, she took her seat in the <a href="Seimas">Seimas</a>.
After her election to the Seimas, Šimonytė joined the parliamentary group of the Homeland Union, despite being officially an independent politician. She was appointed to serve as the chairperson of the audit committee, while also serving on the <a href="European%20affairs">European affairs</a> committee.
2019 presidential election.
In 2018, Šimonytė announced her campaign for <a href="president%20of%20Lithuania">president of Lithuania</a> in the <a href="2019%20Lithuanian%20presidential%20election">2019 presidential election</a>. Standing as an independent candidate, Šimonytė sought the nomination of the <a href="Homeland%20Union">Homeland Union</a> political party, facing only <a href="Vygaudas%20U%C5%A1ackas">Vygaudas Ušackas</a> for the nomination. She ultimately won the nomination, receiving 79% of the vote.
Going into the election as the Homeland Union candidate, Šimonytė was one of the favourites to win, continuously polling in a near-deadlocked tie for first with independent candidate <a href="Gitanas%20Naus%C4%97da">Gitanas Nausėda</a>. The first round of the election was held on 12 May 2019, where Šimonytė narrowly placed first with 31.53% of the vote, ahead of Nausėda's 31.16%. The two subsequently advanced to a run-off election on 26 May, where Šimonytė was defeated by Nausėda after receiving only 33.47% of the vote; she had received less overall votes cast for her in the second round than she did in the first round, having received about 3,200 less votes, compared to Nausėda having received more than 400,000 more votes than he received in the first round.
Prime Minister of Lithuania.
2020 election.
Following the 2019 presidential election, Šimonytė had emerged as an unofficial leader of the <a href="Homeland%20Union">Homeland Union</a> and one of the most prominent politicians affiliated with the party, despite being officially an independent. She stood for reelection to the <a href="Seimas">Seimas</a> in the <a href="2020%20Lithuanian%20parliamentary%20election">2020 parliamentary election</a>, where she once again became one of only three constituency candidates nationwide to win their elections in the first round, this time having received more than 60% of the vote. Following the certification of the election results, it emerged that the Homeland Union had won a plurality of seats, overtaking the incumbent government led by the <a href="Lithuanian%20Farmers%20and%20Greens%20Union">Lithuanian Farmers and Greens Union</a>.
After the election a coalition was expected to be formed between the Homeland Union, the <a href="Liberal%20Movement%20%28Lithuania%29">Liberal Movement</a>, and the <a href="Freedom%20Party%20%28Lithuania%29">Freedom Party</a>, with all three parties proposing Šimonytė to serve as <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Lithuania">Prime Minister</a>. If confirmed, the government would be led by three women: Šimonytė, Liberal Movement leader <a href="Viktorija%20%C4%8Cmilyt%C4%97">Viktorija Čmilytė</a>, and Freedom Party leader <a href="Au%C5%A1rin%C4%97%20Armonait%C4%97">Aušrinė Armonaitė</a>, following in the footsteps of the <a href="Marin%20Cabinet">Marin Cabinet</a> in Finland.
On 9 November, the coalition agreement was signed between the Homeland Union, Liberal Movement, and Freedom Party, paving the way for Šimonytė to become Prime Minister. On 18 November, she announced the proposed makeup of her <a href="%C5%A0imonyt%C4%97%20Cabinet">cabinet</a>. Šimonytė was appointed Prime Minister on 11 December 2020 by President <a href="Gitanas%20Naus%C4%97da">Gitanas Nausėda</a>, becoming the second woman to serve in the role, following <a href="Kazimira%20Prunskien%C4%97">Kazimira Prunskienė</a>.
Domestic policy.
COVID-19 pandemic.
<a href="Skvernelis%20Cabinet">The government of Saulius Skvernelis</a> held its last meeting on 9 December 2020, before the new cabinet is expected to assume office on Friday. Then, PM-designate Šimonytė urged the outgoing government to step up coronavirus measures.
Šimonytė's cabinet was sworn in and started working on 11 December 2020, when the number of cases reached 3067. Two days later, restrictions were put in place.
The vaccination program began on 27 December 2020, as in the rest of the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>. The first to receive the vaccine were healthcare professionals working with COVID-19 patients.
On 4 January, Lithuanian government confirmed backlog of 293 deaths that were previously unaccounted in statistic.
From 15 February, partial lifting of lockdown was made, including decision to re-open small shops and beauty salons. Later, wearing face masks no longer required outdoors.
On 17 March Health Minister <a href="Ar%C5%ABnas%20Dulkys">Arūnas Dulkys</a> suspended the use of vaccine produced by British-Swedish company <a href="AstraZeneca">AstraZeneca</a>. On 18 March the <a href="European%20Medicines%20Agency">European Medicines Agency</a> said the AstraZeneca vaccine is safe. On 22 March 2021, Šimonytė, Speaker of the Seimas Viktorija Čmilytė-Nielsen, and Health Minister Arūnas Dulkys also received the same vaccine.
Foreign policy.
Baltic States.
On 1 January 2021, Šimonytė has taken over the presidency of the Baltic Council of Ministers for a term of one year.
Belarus.
During the meeting with <a href="Sviatlana%20Tsikhanouskaya">Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya</a>, Šimonytė emphasized that Lithuania seeks to further increase pressure on the Belarussian regime. Lithuania also supports the expansion of EU sanctions. During the meeting, the Prime Minister said:
<...> Release of political prisoners, end of repression, and free and democratic elections are the key steps that Belarusians are demanding. Lithuania and the entire democratic world demand the same.
"Belaruskali" scandal.
On 9 August 2021, <a href="United%20States">United States</a> announced sanctions against <a href="Belarus">Belarus</a> potash exporter "Belaruskali". The United States <a href="Office%20of%20Foreign%20Assets%20Control">Office of Foreign Assets Control</a> gave until 8 December 2021 to end all contracts and exporting of "Belaruskali".
On 7 December 2021, one day before the United States sanctions came into action Šimonytė said that the sanctions "have some specifics" and it was not yet clear how they will be implemented in Lithuania.
On 8 December 2021, when the saction had come into effect, <a href="Lithuanian%20Railways">Lithuanian Railways</a> company "LTG Cargo" announced that in November they had made a "pre-paid" contract with "Belaruskali" and will still export it's one million tons of potash products to Baltic Port of <a href="Klaip%C4%97da">Klaipėda</a> in December until January 2022. On 10 December 2021 <a href="Minister%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%2C%20Lithuania">Minister of Foreign Affairs</a> <a href="Gabrielius%20Landsbergis">Gabrielius Landsbergis</a> and Minister of Transport Marius Skuoda had formally informed Šimonytė and <a href="President%20of%20Lithuania">President of Lithuania</a> <a href="Gitanas%20Naus%C4%97da">Gitanas Nausėda</a> about being ready to resign from their duties following the scandal.
When the "Belaruskali" scandal broke, many opposing franctions such as the <a href="Lithuanian%20Farmers%20and%20Greens%20Union">Lithuanian Farmers and Greens Union</a> and <a href="Social%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Lithuania">Social Democratic Party of Lithuania</a> were urging Šimonytė and her government to step down and take on the blame. Many criticised Landsbergis especially who said he had only known of "Belaruskali" advance payments in September for the month of October, and was not informed about the subsequent payments later on. While Lithunian Railways stated they had informed the minster. On 13 December 2021, before announcing her formal decison about the two minsters Lansbergis and Skuoda, and her own government, Šimonytė said in an interview "That it is hard to take on political reponsabilities, and when done, receive more criticism".
On 14 December 2021, Šimonytė had announced she had rejected the letters of resignation from Landsbergis and Skuoda, as well as stating that her government will not step down. “Taking into account the escalated geopolitical situation, as well as the ongoing challenges of COVID-19 and migration, it would be irresponsible to risk and cause uncertainty that would accompany even an attempt to form a new ruling coalition or significantly change the government makeup", Šimonytė said in her statment. Also in her statment she said that she saw no mistakes being made by both Landsbergis and Skuoda, but rather by the company "LTG Cargo" and it's director Mantas Bartuška who still continued to sign contracts with "Belaruskali". Šimonytė also stated that the company's contracts with potash exporter "Belaruskali" should have been submitted to the governmental National Security Commission for evaluation. It was later announced that Mantas Bartuška will step down from his duties in the company.
Political stances.
Foreign policy.
In October 2018, during a debate on foreign policy for the <a href="Homeland%20Union">Homeland Union</a> nomination in the <a href="2019%20Lithuanian%20presidential%20election">2019 presidential election</a>, Šimonytė stated that if elected president, she would increase funding for national security and defense. She has referred to <a href="Russia">Russia</a> as a "state that has broken all international agreements", and called Russia a threat to European security. Additionally, Šimonytė has referred to <a href="Poland">Poland</a> as an ally, and has encouraged improving relations between the two countries. She said that Russia offers its <a href="Sputnik%20V%20COVID-19%20vaccine">Sputnik V COVID-19 vaccine</a> "to the world as another hybrid weapon to divide and rule."
Šimonytė supports scientific data on <a href="climate%20change">climate change</a>, and referred to <a href="Donald%20Trump">Donald Trump</a>'s decision to <a href="United%20States%20withdrawal%20from%20the%20Paris%20Agreement">withdraw</a> from the <a href="Paris%20Agreement">Paris Agreement</a> as a "mistake".
Šimonytė’s new ruling coalition has agreed to defend "those fighting for freedom" in <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>, suggesting that Lithuania's relations with <a href="China">China</a> would not be a priority for her government.
Domestic policy.
Šimonytė has stated that she did not oppose the introduction of <a href="civil%20union">same-sex civil union</a>s to Lithuania, which attracted the support of <a href="LGBT%20rights%20in%20Lithuania">LGBT rights activists</a>. Additionally, Šimonytė stated that while she would never have an <a href="abortion">abortion</a> herself, she would not condemn women who choose to do so.
Šimonytė was criticized by the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Jews%20in%20Lithuania">Jewish community in Lithuania</a> after she opposed removing a plaque to <a href="Jonas%20Noreika">Jonas Noreika</a>, who had signed the declaration to establish <a href="Jewish%20ghettos%20in%20Europe">Jewish ghettos</a> in Lithuania during the <a href="German%20occupation%20of%20Lithuania%20during%20World%20War%20II">German occupation of Lithuania</a> in 1941.
Personal life.
In addition to her native <a href="Lithuanian%20language">Lithuanian</a>, Šimonytė also speaks <a href="English%20language">English</a>, <a href="Polish%20language">Polish</a>, and <a href="Russian%20language">Russian</a>, as well as basic-level <a href="Swedish%20language">Swedish</a>. She is unmarried and has no children. <a href="The%20Good%20Soldier%20%C5%A0vejk">The Good Soldier Švejk</a>, a <a href="satirical">satirical</a> <a href="dark%20comedy">dark comedy</a> by <a href="Czech%20Republic">Czech</a> writer <a href="Jaroslav%20Ha%C5%A1ek">Jaroslav Hašek</a>, is one of Šimonytė's favorite books, whose characters she often publicly quoted during her political career.
